quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Sentence and Synonym
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, mean, phrase. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What is the meaning of the word hardpan?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hard ground

questions.question: What syntactic element is not part of the predicate?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Subject

questions.question: What does the term swale refer to?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Low ground

questions.question: What does the word bog mean?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spongy ground

questions.question: What category is never marked on Non-Finite Verb Phrases such us to have been studying, being studied, etc?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tense

questions.question: Which phrase is a synonym of chase?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hunting ground

questions.question: What phrase is a synonym of jungle?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Uncultivated ground

questions.question: Painter and sculptor Michelangelo is believed to have had homosexual inclinations.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Identify the Operator in the sentence: The football match must have been played last Saturday.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: must

questions.question: Which of these phrases is a synonym of limbo?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Middle ground

questions.question: What sentence contains an Obligatory Adjunct, also known as Predicator Complement?

options.text: The police found him without much difficulty.
She has left her husband for him.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The baby weighs 9 pounds.

questions.question: The nominal clauses are finite dependent clauses that fulfill the functions of Subject, Object and Complement in clause structure. There are four main types: wh-nominal relative, dependent exclamative, wh-interrogative and what other type?

options.text: circumstantial clause as in As soon as I got home, I phoned him.
relative clause as in Ann bought the red coat that had black buttons.
that-clause as in He saw that the bottles were empty.
comparative clause as in Paul won more money than he had expected.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: that-clause as in He saw that the bottles were empty.

questions.question: What sentence is not in the indicative clause type (or mood)?

options.text: What a clever girl she is!

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dont move!

questions.question: In the sentence Cristiano Ronaldo was the best player available, what is the syntactic function of the Noun Phrase the best player available?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Subject Complement

questions.question: Which of these phrases refers to cemetery?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Burying ground

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Kind and Code
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, people, officials. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: It is the process of producing identical copies of a DNA segment asexually.  In 1996 the first successful one of an animal was made. The animals name was Dolly.  Dolly later died, but Richard Seed announced that he intended try it on humans.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cloning

questions.question: On August 17, 1999 this disaster took the lives of 15 000 and injured 23 000 people in western Turkey.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Earthquake

questions.question: Where do we have an example of code, one of the NICE constructions (negation, inversion, code and emphasis)?

options.text: I will stay, if you will.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: I will stay, if you will.

questions.question: Complete this line from a song, featured in the movie Cannibal! The Musical:
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: a baked potato

questions.question: Impeachment stands for quickly removing dangerously criminal officials from high office. The Impeachment Trial in the Senate for this US President commenced on January 7, 1999.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bill Clinton

questions.question: These became more advanced and more popular in the 1990, with some of the most influential ones being  the Super Nintendo Entertainment System, the Sony Playstation, and the Sega Dreamcast.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Video Game consoles

questions.question: This union, made up of European countries, was established by the Maastricht Treaty in 1992. Starting as a trade body it is now an economic and political partnership between its members.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The European Union

questions.question: In which US state is the active Mount Rainier volcano located?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Washington

questions.question: In what sentence is there a modifier in the Adverbial Phrase?

options.text: The French have come to sigh the contract.
I will find the person responsible.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: My shoes are bright red.

questions.question: This womans death was arguably the most shocking one of the decade. She died in 1997 in a car crash while evading paparazzi. The woman was taken to a hospital, but the two-hour efforts of surgeons to save her life were unsuccessful.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Princess Diana

questions.question: Of what kind is the coordination between the clauses in the sentence You should neither ask him for money nor accept it if he offers?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alternation

questions.question: After unsuccessful  talks about oil production and debt repayment, Iraq occupied Kuwait.  In January 1991 the US launched an air attack against military targets in Iraq and Kuwait in this operation.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Desert Storm

questions.question: Although the first one was sent in 1971, it became widely popular in 1998. Its popularity caused explosive growth of the internet.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The E-mail

questions.question: In 1990, this 5000 year old body was found in the Alps. Scientists discovered some tattoos on his leg which indicated that acupuncture was used as far back as the Copper-stone Age.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oetzi

questions.question: This kind of music became largely popular in Europe and America in the 1990s. It is a melodic, free form combination between techno and house, having hypnotic qualities. The first distinctive track of this kind was Age Of Love, released in 1990.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Trance

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Liberty and Austria
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, kissinger, philip. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Anne of Austria was the mother of Louis XIV of France (the Sun King).
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Valeria Messalina was the third wife of this Roman emperor.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Claudius

questions.question: Philip II of France, Richard I of England and Frederick I led this campaign.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Third Crusade

questions.question: Yu the Great was the legendary first Chinese monarch of this dynasty.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Xia Dynasty

questions.question: The British evacuation from which French port was codenamed Operation Dynamo, in 1940?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dunkirk

questions.question: What was the name of the first jet-powered fighter used in World War II?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Me-262

questions.question: The term Blitzkrieg, referring to swift, sudden military offensive, is translated as Thunder War.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which American politician said the following about liberty: They that can give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary safety deserve neither liberty nor safety.”?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Benjamin Franklin

questions.question: One of these cities has been Japans capital in the past.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kyoto

questions.question: Which member of the Nazi Party was known as Adolph Hitlers first architect of the Third Reich?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Albert Speer

questions.question: This German general was nicknamed The Desert Fox due to the skillful military campaigns he waged in North Africa, during World War II.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Erwin Rommel

questions.question: The 1938 incorporation of Austria in Greater Germany under the Nazi Regime is known as this.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anschluss

questions.question: The Punic Wars were a series of three wars fought between these two powers.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rome and Carthage

questions.question: Henry Kissinger held this US post from 1974 to 1977.

options.text: Speaker of the House of Representatives

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Secretary of State

questions.question: How many landing beaches were there in the 1944 Normandy Invasion, known as Operation Overlord?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Five

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Right and World
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, officers, englands. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: His saying, Veni Vidi Vici (I came I saw I conquered) is known all over the world.  His war feats clothed him with glory giving him political power.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Julius Caesar

questions.question: The M1 Carbine is the most mass produced small arm weapon in the United States. Even though it was mainly produced by the Inland Division of General Motors, its design belongs to this famous company.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Winchester

questions.question: This Carthaginian general marched from Spain to Rome across the Alps.  14,000 of his 40,000 troops died because of the harsh climate.  Later, he won the Battle of Cannae.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hannibal

questions.question: Which US President made the following statement: America stands for liberty, for the pursuit of happiness and for the unalienable right for life. This right to life cannot be granted or denied by government because it does not come from the government, it comes from the creator of life.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George W. Bush

questions.question: He was one of the best military officers of Russia during the World War II and involved in the taking of Berlin.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Georgi Zhukov

questions.question: One of the worlds greatest generals. By  the age of 30 he ruled almost half of the world. This great leader died at the peak of his campaign at the age of 33.  His was taught by Aristotle.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alexander The Great

questions.question: This American general  led the invasion of Normandy.  He was also an American president from 1953 to 1961.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dwight Eisenhower

questions.question: Which US President delivered the following words: Ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John F. Kennedy

questions.question: This island was Englands first overseas colony.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Newfoundland

questions.question: These words were spoken by Jed Babbin, a former deputy undersecretary of defence in the first Bush administration, on January 30, 2003: Going to war without France is like going deer hunting without an accordion. You just leave a lot of useless noisy baggage behind.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Which great American leader made the following statement: Any people anywhere, being inclined and having the power, have the right to rise up, and shake off the existing government, and form a new one that suits them better. This is a most valuable - a most sacred right - a right, which we hope and believe, is to liberate the world.”?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Abraham Lincoln

questions.question: The siege of Leningrad lasted just 1 month.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which US President said these words: A democracy is nothing more than mob rule, where fifty-one percent of the people may take away the rights of the other forty-nine.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Jefferson

questions.question: Along with the French general, this British general also led the campaign in Northern Africa during the World War II.  He was accused of not fighting bravely enough, after his lack of success in Operation Lightfoot.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bernard Montgomery

questions.question: How many Medal of Honor citations have been issued during the Vietnam War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 245

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Hong Kong and Jamaica
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, nickname, title. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Sri Lanka was not considered part of the British Raj.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What was the nickname of Tom Cruises character in Top Gun?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Maverick

questions.question: Which one of these actors was not in the Academy Award winning Oliver Stone film Platoon?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tom Cruise

questions.question: On July 1, 1997, the former British colony of Hong Kong reunified with the Peoples Republic of China. This man was the last governor of Hong Kong.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chris Patten

questions.question: Which of these songs was not on Bon Jovis chart-topping 1986 album Slippery When Wet?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ill Be There for You

questions.question: Barbados has never been a British colony.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Britain was not interested in African territories and thus has never controlled any.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Slavery was outlawed in all British colonies in this year.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1834

questions.question: On what album released in 1986 would I find the following lyrics:

options.text: d what my father said and let my mother mold me

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Control - Janet Jackson

questions.question: In 1962 Jamaica gained full independence from the United Kingdom, but before even becoming a British colony, Jamaica was possession of this country.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Spain

questions.question: Australia was officially settled in 1788 as the penal colony of New South Wales. Over the course of the 19th century this many new self-governing Crown Colonies were established on the continent.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 5

questions.question: One of  the results of the Second Anglo-Dutch War, between England and the United Netherlands, was that the city of New Amsterdam was renamed to this.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New York

questions.question: When this significant event took place on January 28, 1986, students worldwide saw it on live television.

options.text: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear plant explodes
The United States Senate allows its debates to be televised
Pope John Paul II officially visits the Synagogue of Rome

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Space Shuttle Challenger explodes

questions.question: The New York Mets were World Champions in baseball in the 1986 world series.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What NBA team won their 16th NBA Championship title on June 8,1986?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Boston Celtics

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: 80s and Bridge
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, aids, ton. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This suspension bridge collapsed due to resonance - a twisting pattern never seen before, took the bridge down.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Tacoma Narrows Bridge

questions.question: The AIDS epidemic was identified and named before 1980.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: This 15,000 ton, German-built ship maintained a route from Tallinn to Stockholm.  In 1994, it sunk to the bottom of the Baltic Sea due to a badly designed bow door.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Estonia Ferry

questions.question: This rap artist, born Stanley Kirk Burrell was known for his lavish tours and catchy hooks.  However, his attempted restyling as a gangsta-rapper was a failure
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: MC Hammer

questions.question: This aircraft was proposed by Boeing in the 80s, but never entered production due to excessive noise from its unducted fan engines and high production costs.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Boeing 7J7

questions.question: One of these TV productions was not released in the 80s.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Saturday Night Live

questions.question: Three of these political events occurred in the 80s. Which one happened earlier?

options.text: The Collapse of the Soviet Union
The Winter of Discontent in the UK

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Winter of Discontent in the UK

questions.question: All of these famous political leaders lost their power in the 80s, except one. Can you spot him?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Francois Mitterrand

questions.question: The TV-series Taxi was first released during this period.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1970s

questions.question: In early 1985 the manufacturer of this drink changed the recipe of the product, but after months of complaints, it was forced by the consumers to restore the original formula.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Coca Cola

questions.question: What southern sitcom, which debuted in 1986, are the following characters from: Julia, Suzanne, Mary Jo, Charlene, Anthony and Bernice?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Designing Women

questions.question: Mel Gibson starred in all of the following four movies. However, only one of them was produced during the 80s.  Which one?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lethal Weapon 2

questions.question: At the time, this was the most complex ship, employing safety measures unseen before.  She was double-bottomed and separated into 16 watertight compartments. Nevertheless, she sank on her maiden voyage.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Titanic

questions.question: This was an attempt to establish the use of the metric system in the United States. However it was not accepted and the US never converted.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The 1975 Metric Conversion Act

questions.question: This tank was built during World War II, but had weight and speed issues.  It never saw battle.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Panzerkampfwagen VIII Maus
